newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Austria to toughen laws on child sex abuse.
newsitem.headline: Austria to toughen laws on child sex abuse.

text.p: The Austrian government said on Wednesday it aimed to introduce tougher laws in a major clampdown on child sex abuse following a number of arrests involving an international child pornography ring.
"The arrests alone show that we have not been doing enough about this sensitive issue," conservative People's Party chairman Andreas Khol told the current affairs magazine News.
"The problem isn't just the length of sentences but also the ineffectiveness of existing laws," he added.
Austrian police over the past week have arrested four men on suspicion of producing pornography in a child prostitution ring spanning central Europe.
The men were also being investigated for alleged involvement in providing children as young as seven, mostly from neighbouring Slovakia, to clients in Vienna.

The People's Party and its senior coalition partner, the Social Democratic Party of Chancellor Franz Vranitzky, will submit a bill to parliament when deputies reconvene on September 19, a Social Democratic party spokesman told Reuters.
He said its priorities would be cracking down on sex tourism and child pornography and tougher sentences for convicted child abusers.
Other measures suggested are that offenders should lose their jobs if they are employed by the state and should have to pay for the psychological care of their victims.
